You’re asking how “costly” Mistral Medium 3.1 is — got it. Let me break it down clearly, without the clutter.

Pricing of Mistral Medium 3.1

Based on the latest data:

  • Input tokens cost $0.40 per 1 million tokens.
  • Output tokens cost $2.00 per 1 million tokens. (Mistral AI)

Some sources present a blended average — around $0.80 per million tokens, assuming a typical 3:1 ratio of inputs to outputs (i.e., 3 units of input for each 1 unit of output). (Artificial Analysis)

Is That “Costly”?

It depends on what you’re comparing it to:

  • Compared to higher-end models like GPT‑4, this is very economical — Mistral Medium 3 (and by extension 3.1) delivers near state-of-the-art performance at up to 8× lower cost. (Mistral AI)

  • An internal efficiency metric shows it delivers GPT‑4-level reasoning at roughly 20 % of the cost, making it a budget-friendly option for serious AI workloads. (Mistral AI)

  • In purely token-based comparison: if you send 1 million tokens, you pay $0.40. When the model responds with 1 million tokens, that’s $2.00 more. A balanced 3:1 exchange might average out to around $0.80 per million tokens — still quite reasonable. (Artificial Analysis)

Bottom Line

  • Is Mistral Medium 3.1 expensive? Not really. It offers high-end performance for a fraction of the cost of premium models like GPT-4.

  • Token costs are modest — $0.40 for inputs and $2.00 for outputs per million tokens, averaging around $0.80 if you assume a normal mix.
